claim: The land cover composition (Figure 1) of the 50,335 km2 MHW watershed is primarily agriculture (33%), forest (27%), and wetlands (24%).
title: FIGURE 1.
caption: Mississippi Headwaters Watershed (MHW) study watershed (hydrologic unit code 0701), National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2011 (Homer et al., 2015), United States Geological Survey (USGS) gaging stations used in Soil Water and Assessment Tool (SWAT) calibration, and the Minneapolis Water Treatment Distribution Service (MWTDS) drinking water intake (approximately co-located with USGS gage 05288500).

claim: Six USGS stream gages were used for discharge calibration/uncertainty analysis and six co-located Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) water quality sampling locations (Figure 1) were used for calibration/uncertainty analysis of sediment load, total nitrogen (TN) load, and total phosphorus (TP) load.
title: FIGURE 1.
caption: Mississippi Headwaters Watershed (MHW) study watershed (hydrologic unit code 0701), National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2011 (Homer et al., 2015), United States Geological Survey (USGS) gaging stations used in Soil Water and Assessment Tool (SWAT) calibration, and the Minneapolis Water Treatment Distribution Service (MWTDS) drinking water intake (approximately co-located with USGS gage 05288500).

title: FIGURE 2.
caption: (a) Inter-class land cover changes from 2011 to 2050 by scenario, where colors represent the new land cover class in 2050. (b) Net land cover changes by scenario. CROP, cropland; DEV, developed; FRST, forest; PAST, pasture; WETL, wetland. Labels above bars in panel b represent percentage of total watershed area that changed.

claim: For example, at USGS 05227500 (Figure 1), median seasonal changes were +2.3% to +6.7% (sediment), +3.5% to +4.5% (TN), and +4.8% to +6.3% (TP).
